Problem:
Consider a function \\( z(t) \\) that is an analytic solution to the partial differential equation \\( \\frac{\\partial z}{\\partial t} = Pz \\), where P is a linear operator. Evaluate how the Fourier transform \\( \\mathcal{F}(z) = \\int_{-\\infty}^\\infty e^{-i\\omega t} z(t) dt \\) influences the system's behavior.

If the Fourier transform \\( \\mathcal{F}(z) \\) is computed at time \\( t = 0 \\), and then \\( z(t) \\) is allowed to evolve under \\( \\frac{\\partial z}{\\partial t} = Pz \\) without further modification, will the nature of \\( z(t) \\) at \\( t = T \\) be identical to if it was evolved directly under \\( \\frac{\\partial z}{\\partial t} = Pz \\) from the beginning?
Explanation: The Fourier transform is a linear operator and does not influence the physical laws governing the evolution of \\( z(t) \\). Since it is a separate mathematical construct used for analysis and not a physical intervention in the system, it will not alter the natural evolution of \\( z(t) \\) under its governing partial differential equation.
